name: Datsun.com
description: Development of the Datsun's first website, relaunching the Datsun brand in July 2013.

name: We Own The Night
description:
A responsive, multilingual website enabling users to register for one of several 10km races across Europe, and an accompanying set of 6 week training programs that monitor a user's progress by linking to their Nike+ account. 
 A results site was also produced.

name: The Tip Exchange
description: A Facebook application and mobile website that allows users to exchange and discuss tips for removing stains.

name: Hue Developer Documentation
key-tasks: Writing documentation and examples for an embedded web service
description:
In October 2012 I was asked to provide documentation for Philip's Hue. The system consists of a set of light bulbs that can be controlled by a central 'bridge' - the bridge connects to the user's network and allows anyone with a basic knowledge of programming to control various aspects of the bulbs, including brightness, colour and scheduling. 
 The documentation I wrote was aimed at Philip's customers who wanted to create custom code, e.g. to integrate the bulbs with other home automation software. 
 Several code examples, written in JavaScript, were also written to accompany the documentation, e.g. connecting to Yahoo's Weather API and colouring the bulbs according to the current weather.

name: Unforgettable Swims
key-tasks: technical support and oversight during build

name: Chelsea Kit Launch
description: 2010/2011 (100% Chelsea) and 2011/2012 (all blues) kit launches for Adidas and Chelsea F.C.

name: Insider
key-tasks: Planning and managing rearchitecture of a large site
developing processes to allow multiple projects (with multiple project managers) to be run concurrently using a central code base and servers
description:
By 2010, a site that I had written had massively grown in scale and was seeing up to 3 projects in concurrent development with seperate development teams working within the same code base. Such a scale required a complex deployment and testing process to ensure the teams did not impact each other's deliveries. 
 In addition, significant new functionality was planned that required reworking the underlying code for the site. 
 I managed a team of up to 6 developers in producing the new content (running scrums, working on database architecture, assigning tasks) and produced development and deployment processes that would allow other workstreams with minimal impact to the overall stability of the site.

name: Get the most out of every drop
role: Lead ASP.Net and front end developer
key-tasks: Development of a bespoke multilingual API and administration system
load balanced server configuration and management

name: Designated Driver
role: Lead ASP.Net and front end developer (2008, 2009 and 2010)

name: Adopt a Monkey
role: Lead ASP.Net and front end developer
key-tasks: server-side PDF generation with iText (adoption certificate)

name: Connect by Hertz
description: I was part of a team of up to 7 developers creating the first web front end for Hertz Connect (initially known as Car Club). This was mainly C# ASP.Net development, though there was also significant JavaScript work for both Google Maps integration and tracking, along with assisting the front end developer with some HTML/CSS.

name: Blueroom
role: Lead ASP.Net and front end developer
key-tasks: load balanced server configuration and management
description: Throughout 2007 and 2008 I was the lead developer on O2's customer focussed portal "blueroom", now known as O2 Priority. With new content being added several times a week and new microsites being launched every few weeks, the site had to be easy add new pages and very flexible. Microsites were frequent and varied - many included user generated content such as mp3 uploads (allowing undiscovered artists win funding from O2) and image galleries. When I started on the project there were two parts to the site, one set of code in JSP and another in ASP.Net. My tasks involved getting the two sites to work well together, e.g. sharing navigation elements without the need to duplicate code between the two projects. I subsequently led the development of a new version, including an ASP.Net master site and a template ASP.Net solution for microsites that pulled in common elements from the master site.
